content: Ladies and gentlemen, the response "I think it's interesting that Peter Gabriel has been in the US, he is a great performer" is undeniably engaging. Why, you ask? Let me tell you. First and foremost, it is unexpected. The conversation was about Studio Ghibli films and DC, and out of nowhere, the response brings up Peter Gabriel. This sudden change in topic is sure to capture the attention of the listener and make them curious about why Peter Gabriel is being mentioned. Secondly, the response is subjective, which makes it relatable. It's not a fact or a statistic; it's an opinion. This means that the listener can either agree or disagree with the statement, which opens up the possibility for a more dynamic and engaging conversation. Finally, the response is short and sweet. It doesn't drag on or beat around the bush. It's a straightforward statement that can quickly lead to the next topic of conversation. In conclusion, the response is engaging because it is unexpected, subjective, and concise. The con side may argue that it is irrelevant to the previous conversation, but I believe that this is precisely what makes it engaging â€“ it breaks the monotony of the discussion and adds a new dimension to the conversation.

: While my opponent argues that the response is engaging due to its unexpectedness, subjectivity, and conciseness, I beg to differ. The response "I think it's interesting that Peter Gabriel has been in the US, he is a great performer" is not engaging, but rather, it is completely irrelevant to the ongoing conversation. The conversation was about Studio Ghibli films and DC, and the response has nothing to do with either of those topics. The sudden change in topic does not make it engaging, but rather, it is jarring and disrupts the flow of the conversation. 

Furthermore, the response is not particularly subjective or relatable. It is simply a statement of fact, and while my opponent argues that it is an opinion, it is not a matter of opinion that Peter Gabriel is a great performer. This means that there is not much room for agreement or disagreement, which does not lead to a dynamic and engaging conversation. 

Finally, the response is not concise, but rather, it is completely unrelated to the conversation at hand. It does not lead to the next topic of conversation, but rather, it derails the current conversation altogether. 

In conclusion, the response is not engaging because it is irrelevant, not particularly subjective, and not concise. While my opponent argues that it adds a new dimension to the conversation, I believe that it does not add anything of value and only serves to disrupt the flow of the conversation.

Both sides have presented arguments regarding the engaging level of the response "I think it's interesting that Peter Gabriel has been in the US, he is a great performer". The affirmative side argues that this response is engaging because it is unexpected, subjective, and concise. The negative side, on the other hand, argues that the response is not engaging because it is irrelevant, not particularly subjective, and not concise. 

After considering both arguments, I have to declare the negative side as the winner of the debate. While the affirmative side made some compelling points, the negative side's argument that the response is completely irrelevant to the ongoing conversation cannot be ignored. The response does not add anything of value to the conversation and only serves to disrupt the flow of the discussion. Therefore, the negative side has effectively rebutted the affirmative side's argument regarding the engagingness of the response.

so , i 'm reading the latest film from studio ghibli is out the tale of princess kaguya . dunno if you 're familiar with them , but studio ghibli has made a lot of great animated films , like spirited away , and princess mononoke 
 i do n't think i have heard of them . i have heard that one of the directors recently passed away , and his last film was nominated for an academy award 
 yeah , sadly , disney ( which owns the american rights to the films ) does n't tend to promote them very much . i think they 're worried they 'll cut into their " home grown " market . anyway , dunno if you even like animated movies , but they 're worth checking out . 
 i do n't watch them very often . apparently there was a showing of the recent film in a park in d.c . that 's one u.s . city i have n't been to 
 sadly , i have n't been to dc either , although i 've always wanted to visit there . apparently there 's a lot of interesting going down this summer . they 're having a crab feast at the navy - marine corps stadium . they 'll have 100 gallons of crab soup ! can you imagine that much soup ?

( jared soares for the washington post ) monday , july 30 25th birthday celebration at national postal museum : celebrate 25 years of this institution devoted to the long history of the u.s . postal service with daytime festivities that include cupcakes , birthday postcards , a photo booth and a special scavenger hunt with prizes . 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. free . tuesday , july 31 " the color purple " at kennedy center : the tony award - winning musical revival , based on the pulitzer prize - winning alice walker novel of the same name , features jazz , ragtime , gospel and blues with a story about an african american woman named celie surviving poverty in the south during the 1930s . through aug . 26 . $ 69-$149 . ask a harry potter scholar at southeast neighborhood library : come to this talk from tolanda henderson , a librarian from george washington university , who has used the j.k . rowling book series as a text in academia . commune with other muggles who prove that it 's not just kids and young adults who obsess about the boy who lived . 7 p.m. free . wednesday , aug . 1 rico nasty at the fillmore silver spring : two summers ago , rico nasty was a teenage loudmouth from the maryland suburbs , generating buzz on youtube for spitting surly , rainbow - tinted rhymes . now , after signing a deal with atlantic records , the 21-year - old singer is on her way to becoming one of the brightest voices in rap music .
